_header: And fetched his fellow there as he lay his store
Title(s): Summoner’s Tale; ‘Dividing of a fart into twelve’; Canterbury Tales
_description: Lines 2159-2294 of Geoffrey Chaucer’s Summoner’s Tale (3255) of the Canterbury Tales, rearranged in this MS as part of the restructuring of the work to produce a round-trip journey.

Alnwick455.First Lines:
And fet his felawe ther as he leyd his storeHe lokid as he were a
                    wild bore…
Alnwick455.Last Lines:
…And Ienkyn hath I wonne a newe gounMy tale is doon wee be
                    almost at toun
Alnwick455.Note:
III. 2229 omitted; spurious line follows 2230; 2185-6 reversed; f.
                        239v left blank.
Alnwick455.Attributed Title:
Here endeth the tale of the Sompnoure within þe boke wryten (f.
                        237v); Here endith the Sompnoure his tale (f. 239); Here
                    begynnyth Chawcere his tale of Mellebe and Prudence (f. 240; the prose tale of
                        Melibee follows these concluding lines of Summoner’s
                        Tale in this uniquely-ordered MS.
